In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  has  requested  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
provide technical assistance (TA) to further develop the insurance sector. This is in line with the 
government’s priorities for reforms and sustainable improvement of Uzbekistan’s finance and 
banking system, and measures to develop the microfinance and nonbank financial subsectors 
through comprehensive activities set out in the government’s action plan for 2011–2015. The TA 
is  in  line  with  the  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–20161 and  included  in  the  county 
operations business plan, 2012-2014.2 A reconnaissance mission was fielded on 28 November–
2 December 2011,3 at which time an understanding was reached with the government on the TA 
impact, outcome, outputs, cost estimates, financing plan, implementation arrangements, and 
consultants’ terms of reference. The design of the TA was discussed in particular with the State 
Insurance  Supervisory  Board  (SISB),  the  insurance  market  regulator.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  As of December 2011, Uzbekistan had 30 commercial banks with 822 branches and 
about  1,800  minibank  offices,  34  microcredit  organizations,  48  pawnshops,  46  leasing 
companies, and 37 insurance companies (34 general insurance companies, 2 life insurance 
companies, and 1 reinsurance company). There is also one stock exchange. Total assets of 
commercial banks were $15.3 billion or the equivalent of 35.3% of gross domestic product (GDP) 
in 2011. The securities market is shallow—government and corporate bonds, and corporate 
stocks are the only three financial instruments.  
 
3.  The insurance market penetration5 of 0.4% of GDP in 2010 is low compared with the 
global average of 6.9% of GDP and emerging markets average of 3.0% of GDP. Insurance 
spending per capita is also low—the insurance density rate equaled $4.506 per capita in 2010 
compared with the global average of $627.00.7  
 
4.  The market is dominated by state-owned insurers—Uzbekinvest, Uzagrosugurta, and 
Kafolat. Uzbekinvest is the largest insurer in terms of investments (45.0% of the total held by the 
subsector) followed by Uzagrosugurta (7.0% of the total held by the subsector). Underwriting 
premiums in 2011 equaled $129 million, an increase of 36.6% over 2010, while claims equaled 
$25.1 million, an increase of 65.7%. This resulted in a low loss ratio (claims paid to premiums 
earned) of 19.5% and allowed the industry to continue to earn large underwriting profits (the 
difference between premiums earned and claims paid). Of total earnings held by insurance firms, 
45.1% was held in banks as deposits, 41.2% was invested in securities and corporate bonds, 
6.5% was invested in real estate, and 5.6% in equity capital. 
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Uzbekistan, 2012–2016. Manila 
2  ADB. 2012. Country Operations Business Plan: Uzbekistan, 2012-2014. Manila. 
3  In connection with the Tashkent International Insurance and Reinsurance Conference in April 2011, the design of

Participants of the Uzbekistan Insurance Market, as well as other relevant stakeholders. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 November 2012. 
5  Insurance penetration, calculated as the ratio of total insurance premiums to GDP, indicates the growth of 
insurance consumption. Insurance density, calculated as the ratio of total insurance premiums to total population, 
indicates how much each inhabitant of a country spends each year for insurance services. 
6  To calculate the insurance density ratio, ADB used the National Statistics and Ministry of Finance data on 
insurance premium amounts collected, population, and GDP. 
7  World Insurance in 2010. Sigma No 2/2011, Swiss Re.

2   
 
 
5.  Major insurance products include compulsory motor insurance, compulsory employer's 
liability, contractor's all-risk insurance, property insurance (against pledges and all types of 
catastrophes), and export credit insurance. The introduction of mandatory motor third-party 
liability insurance in 2008 helped the insurance market expand. Companies are the major 
insurance  buyers.  In  2011,  their  contribution  to  total  premiums  was  73.7%  ($94.1  million) 
compared  with  26.3%  collected  from  individuals.  Insurance  penetration  is  concentrated  in 
Tashkent City with about 60% of collected insurance premiums. The remaining 40% come from 
the 13 regions where about 90% of the population resides. 
 
6.  ADB provided TA for the Development of the Insurance Industry,8 approved on 11 May 
2000 for $0.30 million. That TA supported the initial development of Uzbekistan’s insurance 
market by (i) supporting background work for the development of a medium-term insurance sector 
reform strategy, (ii) bringing insurance regulations broadly in line with international standards with 
certain  transitional  measures,  (iii)  revising  the  insurance  law,9 and  (iv)  strengthening  the 
institutional capacity of SISB to ensure adequate supervision of insurance companies. SISB 
views the strengthening of capacity for insurance market supervision as a key area of focus.  
 
7.  The slow penetration of general insurance and negligible growth of life insurance can be 
attributed to regulatory, social, human development, and cultural factors, as well as the state-
dominated market structure. Some of the major impediments include (i) weak competition in the 
insurance market, where premium discounting is a common practice; (ii) insurance agents’ poor 
knowledge about the products they sell; (iii) an unbalanced relationship between the insured 
and  the  insurer,  which  favors  industry  profitability  but  undermines  the  development  of  the 
market;  (iv)  difficulty  in  regulating  solvency  requirements  of  private  insurers;  (v)  lack  of 
separation between shareholder funds and policyholder funds; and (vi) low per capita income. 
 
8.  Finance sector regulators and policymakers can play an important role in overcoming 
these obstacles. They can promote policies that enable the market to develop while helping 
build and retain consumer confidence and trust. This can be achieved through regulations and 
supervision  that  promote  a  safe,  sound,  competitive,  and  accessible  insurance  sector. 
Promotion of information sharing with consumers, both firms and individuals, can also help 
deepen the insurance market. 
 
9.  The key development issues to be addressed by the TA are the regulatory frameworks, 
and  the  capacity  of  SISB  and  other  relevant  authorities.  Greater  penetration  of  insurance 
services can play an important role in diversifying the finance sector, which is dominated by 
banks, and in boosting the ability of the financial system to manage financial shocks and periods 
of uncertainty. This will contribute to the stability of economic processes through better risk 
management, bolster social welfare through greater financial security, and stimulate economic 
growth by encouraging the flow of long-term private capital for infrastructure investment. 
 
10.  The TA will reinforce the active steps that the government and market participants have 
already taken to create more favorable conditions for the expansion of a functional and efficient 
insurance sector in Uzbekistan. This is needed to help mitigate insurable risks for small and 
medium-sized enterprises and individuals, and increase the accumulation of contractual savings 
used for investment in the country. In particular, the TA will help improve the efficiency of 
supervision of the insurance system, and deepen insurance penetration through better product 
design and use of alternative distribution channels. An action plan for the development of the 
                                                
8  ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance for Development of the Insurance Industry. Manila (TA 3438-REG).

insurance sector over the medium and long term will help strengthen the confidence of market 
participants by enhancing the capacity of SISB, aiding the implementation and observance of 
international insurance principles and standards, and promoting greater customer protection. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be greater outreach of insurance. The outcome will be a 
stronger policy and regulatory environment for insurance. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will deliver four outputs:  
(i)  Recommendations on changes to the policy and regulatory framework. The 
TA will assess compliance with international standards such as the insurance 
core principles (ICPs) of the International Association of Insurance Supervisors 
(IAIS)  and  international  financial  reporting  standards  to  uncover  policy  and 
regulatory gaps in the insurance market of Uzbekistan. 
 
(ii)  Development of an electronic document management system. The TA will 
(a) analyze the existing system for submission of returns, off-site and on-site 
analysis, preparation of reports, and for archiving returns and reports; (b) develop 
a  web-based  information  technology  tool  capable  of  seamless  integration  of 
reporting by insurers and insurance intermediaries, and of carrying out analyses 
of core insurer functions, e.g., solvency, reinsurance, investments; (c) develop 
and  maintain  a  reliable  data  base  to  track  online  reporting  by  insurers  and 
intermediaries  as  well  as  various  on-site  and  off-site  analyses  and  internal 
reports; and (d) pilot-test the electronic document management system. 
 
(iii)  Exploration of new insurance products and distribution channels. The TA 
will (a) explore measures to promote access to the insurance market for the low-
income population; (b) suggest indicative designs and actuarial pricing for new 
insurance products such as life and annuities, financing solutions to manage 
disaster  risks,  and  microinsurance;  and  (c)  develop  alternative  distribution 
channels to expand the outreach. 
 
(iv)  Capacity building for insurance regulator and market participants. The TA 
will  provide  training  and  workshops  to  (a)  strengthen  skills  in  prudential 
supervision (off-site and on-site) with specific reference to solvency, investments, 
reinsurance, and anti-money-laundering measures and combating the financing 
of terrorism; (b) help SISB staff attend the IAIS meetings; (c) provide training on 
the electronic document management system; and (d) devise a framework for 
setting up a training center—Sugurta Olami (World of Insurance)—to help meet 
the professional training and education needs of insurance market participants in 
collaboration with an internationally accredited, professional body of actuaries 
and the Tashkent Financial Institute.

4   
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and their travel and per diem, office facilities, 
meeting  venues  for  workshops,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.   The TA will be implemented over 30 months, from January 2013 to June 2015. SISB will 
be the executing agency and will appoint a TA coordinator who will coordinate all outputs with 
the team of consultants.  
 
15.  The  TA  will  cover  remuneration,  travel,  and  per  diem  of  consultants,  as  well  as 
workshops, seminars, training, and miscellaneous expenses. Disbursements under the TA will 
be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
16.   The  TA  will  require  21.5  person-months  of  consulting  services—two  international 
individual consultants for a total of 6.5 person-months, one international firm for a total of 7 
person-months, and one national individual consultant for 8 person-months. ADB will engage 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from  time  to  time)  using  the  individual  consultant  selection  system  for  individuals  or  the 
consultants’  qualifications  selection    for  a  firm.  The  consultants  should  have  expertise  in 
prudential regulation, supervision, and policy issues related to the insurance sector, risk and risk 
management  concepts,  insurance  product  areas,  both  life  and  nonlife,  including  health 
insurance,  agriculture,  and  disaster  products.  The  consultants  will  be  required  to  provide 
deliverables  consistent  with  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  activities,  outputs,  and 
delivery dates. The terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The  TA  will  follow  the  standard  monitoring  and  supervision  procedures  for  ADB-
administered TA. Good practice and lessons will be disseminated through policy dialogue with 
the government and in seminar and training materials and knowledge products published under 
the TA. An evaluation of performance and outcomes will be carried out at the end of the TA and 
reflected in a TA completion report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for Insurance Sector Development, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 21.5 person-months of consulting services—
two international individual consultants for a total of 6.5 person-months, one international firm 
for a total of 7 person-months, and one national individual consultant for 8 person-months. The 
individual consultants will be engaged using the individual consultant selection system and the 
firm  will  be  engaged  using  the  consultants’  qualifications  selection  method.  The  team  of 
consultants will be required to provide deliverables consistent with the design and monitoring 
framework activities, outputs, and delivery dates. Reports are to be of high quality and produced 
in English with copies in Russian. Precise work timelines and deliverables with dates will be 
defined at inception, documented in the final inception report, and agreed with the executing 
agency,  the  State  Insurance  Supervisory  Board  (SISB),  and the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB). 
 
A.  International Consultants (6.5 person-months) 
 
2.  Insurance regulation expert and team leader (5 person-months). The expert should 
preferably have a postgraduate degree in economics or finance, or equivalent, with about 12 
years of international experience in the respective field of expertise. The expert should have 
profound technical knowledge of prudential regulation, supervision, and policy issues related to 
the insurance sector. The expert must have sound experience in insurance supervision and in 
carrying  out  assessments  of  compliance  with  insurance  core  principles  (ICPs)  of  the 
International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS). Working experience in developing 
countries, preferably in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), is an advantage. The 
expert will: 
(i)  carry out an assessment of compliance with IAIS ICPs (2011) as part of the 
country assessment (policy, regulatory, and supervisory) and prepare a report on 
the  findings  of  the  assessment,  i.e.,  gaps  uncovered  and  action  required, 
including capacity building needs; 
(ii)  assess  the  existing  regulatory  framework  to  identify  barriers  to  insurance 
development; 
(iii)  lead in developing an action plan in close collaboration with the government and 
other experts; 
(iv)  undertake discussions, meetings, and interviews with stakeholders, and collect 
and analyze information and data; 
(v)  provide recommendations on revised regulations; 
(vi)  lead the preparation of training programs; 
(vii)  develop a white paper for the establishment of a training center—Sugurta Olami 
(World of Insurance); 
(viii)  participate in and present findings and recommendations at the workshops with 
stakeholders; and 
(ix)  act as a team leader and coordinate the work of other experts and submission 
requirements. 
 
3.  Insurance  market  specialist  (1.5  person-months). The  specialist  should  preferably 
have a postgraduate degree in economics or finance and at least 10 years of experience in the 
insurance sector. The specialist should have good knowledge of insurance and other financial 
services, risk, and risk management concepts. The specialist should be familiar with insurance 
product  areas,  both  life  and  nonlife,  including  health  insurance,  agriculture,  and  disaster 
products. The specialist should also be familiar with all phases of the insurance process, e.g., 
education, marketing, sales (agency and brokerage), underwriting, technical aspects (pricing,

10  Appendix 3 
reserving, role of the actuary and other professionals, financial management), claims processes, 
and customer service. The specialist should understand emerging markets and developing 
economies, particularly constraints related to infrastructure, education and training, culture, and 
the roles of the state and  the private sector. Working experience in developing countries, 
preferably in the CIS, is an advantage. The specialist will:  
(i)  study  the  existing  insurance  products  in  Uzbekistan  and  identify  barriers  to 
access to insurance and the constraints on developing new product lines; 
(ii)  conduct  discussions,  meetings,  and  interviews  with  stakeholders  and  collect 
information and data; 
(iii)  provide recommendations on new product lines; 
(iv)  prepare short briefing reports and discussion notes for follow-up discussions with 
the government, and provide inputs to reports as required; 
(v)  contribute to the presentation material as required; 
(vi)  take part in trainings, field visits, and dialogue workshops and coordinate work 
with other experts as necessary; and 
(vii)  coordinate work with the team leader. 
 
B.  Insurance Information System Software Development Firm (7 person-months) 
 
4.  The purpose of this assignment is to develop an electronic document management 
system to assist submission of returns by insurers and intermediaries and to improve efficiency 
and  effectiveness  of  off-site  and  on-site  inspections.  The  firm  should  have  documented 
experience in developing information technology (IT) tools and software for financial regulation, 
supervision, and policy issues. This assignment requires 2 domain experts (one international for 
5 person months and one national consultant for 2 person months) with at least 10 years of 
experience as IT specialists in financial services, preferably insurance; should be familiar with 
on-site and off-site inspections and in designing an integrated on-site and off-site monitoring 
system; and have experience in developing compliance-related software. Working experience in 
developing countries, preferably in the CIS, is an advantage. ADB will engage consultants in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) 
to  be  contracted  either  as  individual  consultants  or  through  a  firm  using  the  consultants’ 
qualifications selection. The firm will: 
(i)  undertake an inventory of regulatory returns and disclosures by insurers and 
insurance intermediaries, and prepare a report with recommendations to make 
the process more efficient and effective; 
(ii)  analyze  data,  software  and  hardware  requirements,  and  compatibility  of  the 
systems currently used by insurance market participants; 
(iii)  develop an electronic document management system for online submission of 
regulatory returns and disclosures, carry out analysis on a sole-entity basis as 
well as on an aggregate basis, and set up an archive of returns and disclosures; 
(iv)  review and certify the electronic document management system with SISB and 
with relevant stakeholders, and conduct pilot-tests and training; 
(v)  develop  operation  manuals  and  conduct  training  for  SISB  and  industry 
participants; 
(vi)  undertake meetings and interviews with stakeholders and collect and analyze 
information and data; 
(vii)  coordinate with the consulting team; and 
(viii)  participate in trainings, field visits, and workshops.
